prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Employee's Personal Skill, Knowledge and Experience

para.paratext: An employee is entitled to continue to use his or her personal skill, knowledge and experience after the employment relationship has been terminated.[1] In Sir W.C. Leng & Co. v. Andrews,[2] the court held that the doctrine of confidential information:

… does not mean that an employer can prevent bis employee from using the skill and knowledge in his trade or profession … That information and additional skill he is entitled to use for the benefit of himself and the benefit of the public who gain the advantage of his having had such admirable instruction.

The court thus attempted to distinguish between “trade secrets” and “skill and knowledge” by classifying trade secrets or confidential business information such as the names of customers as “objective knowledge”, and skill and knowledge, including aptitudes, dexterity, and manual and mental ability as “subjective knowledge”.

In R.L. Crain Ltd. v. Ashton,[3] the court held that a defendant will not succeed where the information claimed to be “skill and knowledge”—in this case, how to construct a printing press—could not have been retained in the defendant's memory.

Where a person has acquired knowledge, some of which is confidential and some not, the person is only required to avoid using the information of a confidential nature. In Chevron Standard Ltd. v. Home Oil Co.,[4] the defendant, a geologist, was entitled to use the general geological knowledge acquired by him during his previous service with the plaintiff, knowledge such as the location of large geological structures. The defendant did not disclose to his new employer the location of geographic anomalies which could have signaled the presence of oil. By remaining ignorant and silent regarding the specific confidential business information belonging to the plaintiff, the defendant was judged not to have infringed the plaintiff's right to its confidential business information, and as a result, the action was dismissed.[5]
Triplex Safety Glass Co. v. Scorah, [1937] 4 All E.R. 693 (Ch.).
Sir W.C. Leng & Co. v. Andrews, [1909] 1 Ch. 763 at p. 773.
